characters: ON THE ROOF OF THE ABBEY, (INTERCUT)
SOMETHING TENTACLE-LIKE DROPS DOWN ON HIS SHOULDER
FACE TO FACE WITH THE ALIEN
ON THE ROOF OF THE ABBEY
IN THE CORRIDOR JUST OUTSIDE THE LIBRARY
THE OTHER SIDE OF THE OCEAN
AT THE END OF THE HALL
THE HUGE DUMP TANK OF WATER
ON THE ROOF OF THE MONASTERY
THE DOOR TO THE TECHNOLOGY ROOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vast room filled with rows of wooden tables with low be between aisle after aisle of floor-to-ceiling wooden shel jammed to capacity with BOOKS of all shapes and sizes.  M of books, from the looks of it. From each book hangs a long CHAIN, long enough to allow t book to be carried only as far as the nearest table.

dialogues.speaker: A CORPULENT MONK
dialogues.text: In his fifties, and the Librarian by his stern affect, hi position behind a broad, but also old oak desk, and the l KEY hanging from his belt.  He watches the few stragglers their chain bound volumes to the shelves and head for the then rises and joins them...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CORRIDOR JUST OUTSIDE THE LIBRARY
dialogues.text: John leans against the wall as Philip exits. Mattias is nowhere to be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother Philip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feeding the mind instead of the body again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My training has taught me to feed what's hungry. Philip pats his broad stomach and heads down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As did mine.  As long as you're alone. Enjoy yourself -- and remember, no book leaves the library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I forget?  Have a good meal... John watches the corpulent librarian head down the stairs When he's gone from sight John lifts the bottom of his ca to reveal Mattias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect. They move into the library...

dialogues.speaker: THE MEDIEVAL SECTION
dialogues.text: The oldest books. John moves to the stacks. Mattias trots over to a particular bench and sits. This is his regular place.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE SHELVES
dialogues.text: John stands on toe tips to retrieve an ancient Tome. He runs his fingers over the familiar leather binding. A smile plays across his lips. He carries the book, places it on the edge of the table s there is slack in the chain. Sits on the bench next to the dog. Clears his throat, opens the book, begins to read... John (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the year of our Lord 1348 I, Brother Gerhado of the Minorite Abbey helped bury the Abbot and my sixty fellow monks -- VOICE O/S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes, I think you'd like that. John turns to find --

dialogues.speaker: THE ABBOT
dialogues.text: Leader of the monastery.  In his seventies but looks youn His Cassock is adorned with a large, ornately carved, woo CHAIN in place of a rope belt.  He crosses to the table. John closes the book and stands, head bowed in respect. John

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abbot, I -- I didn't think anyone would -- ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind?  Just Philip, if he knew.  I passed him on the way up.  He said you'd come  in alone.  I knew better. He scratches the back of Mattias' neck. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mattias.  How are you, boy? The dog snuffles in response. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what Philip says about Mattias' hair and his breathing.  You'll have to  take him out of here. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He likes when I read to him and -- I  can't -- John looks down sheepishly.  Though nearly forty, he feel almost adolescent in the presence of the Abbot.   The Abbot pulls a large key from his pocket. ABBOT (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone must have left this one unlocked. Take the book with you. He hands the key to John, who is shocked -- this is a great honor. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, I --? ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle tells me you did a good job at the glassworks today. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll reserve judgement until the patient lives. John crosses to the shelf and unlocks his book. He returns the key. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will get easier.  Father Anselm was... an unexpected loss.  You'll do fine. The Abbot walks towards the door... ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just have it back before the end of lunch. Oh -- And I didn't see you in here. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (to Mattias)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go upstairs, boy. John takes his book -- Moves to a spiral wooden staircase Mattias at his heels. Goes UP --

dialogues.speaker: INTO THE BELL TOWER
dialogues.text: The mechanics of the bell tower -- all ropes and wooden c cast scary shadows. A doorway leads to --

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOF OF THE ABBEY
dialogues.text: Thick with sandy dust.  The wood shows through thin patch We PULL BACK TO REVEAL what we think is the roof of the A is actually --

dialogues.speaker: THE SURFACE OF ARCEON
dialogues.text: The door has opened onto the SURFACE OF A PLANTOID! The curving horizon broken only by the very top of the Abbey bell tower poking through from the levels below.   SMOKE curls from vents set into the surface. Sunken areas of the planet's sirface are SEAS. This is ARCEON. An manmade orbiter. A shell of lightweight foamed steel, five miles in diamet Constructed by The Company on Special Order with habitabl level within finished in whatever material suits its end This orbiter, for reasons to be discovered later, has bee sheathed in wood.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Walks to the shore of an inland SEA. Sits on a bare patch of wood.  Looks up. His eyes grow accustomed to --

dialogues.speaker: THE NIGHT SKY
dialogues.text: Freckled with tiny dots of light. Stars.  Spread across the inky void. Bathe Arceon's surface with their celestial glow. John smiles at Mattias, breathes deep.  The atmosphere up here is thinner, but fresher.  He opens the book. Reads aloud -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the year of our Lord 1348 I, Brother Gerhado of the Minorite Abbey helped bury the Abbot and my sixty fellow monks, day by day, one by one, until I am the only  one left.  I stayed as long as I could bear  it, then with my dog --  Mattias lifts his ears at this part.  His favorite part. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - fled.  I have put this to parchment lest this pestilence - this Black Death -  stay my hand. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was finished by another hand... John closes the book.  Something catches his eye -- Something among the myriad points of light in the sky. Millions of miles away:

dialogues.speaker: ONE OF THE STARS
dialogues.text: Brighter than the rest.  MOVING. Fast enough to leave a faint trail. Across the stars.  And down... A comet. John stands.  Watches --

dialogues.speaker: THE STAR
dialogues.text: Growing brighter. Drawing nearer.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Joined by three other MONKS. They are older than he. The Four men watch the sky...

dialogues.speaker: THE STAR
dialogues.text: Brighter still.  Closer.

dialogues.speaker: MORE MONKS
dialogues.text: Two dozen.  A hundred. They come up through the planet's surface. Out of wooden trap doors.  Join the others. Days pass. Now three hundred. Necks bowed back. Mouths agape. A SUBTITLE identifies... RELIGIOUS COLONY ARCEON ----------------------- POPULATION: 350 Exiles CRIME:  Political Heresy

dialogues.speaker: THE STAR
dialogues.text: Fills the sky. Burns brighter still as it hits the planetoid's atmospher

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SURFACE OF ARCEON
dialogues.text: Hundreds of Monks shield their eyes as the ship -- the st ROARS over their heads.  Trailing FIRE -- John holds up his hands - to touch a star -- Skin BLISTERS as it passes over him, He turns and watches as it -- Arcs downward --

dialogues.speaker: WHOMP- SSSSSSSSSS --
dialogues.text: PLUMES of steam rise into the air. The water boils.  Fish bob to the surface.  Bloated.  Dea

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Is the first to hit the shore. Small leather and wood fishing boats tossed by the wake. His coracle is the first into the water. The others running up behind him. He cannot hear the SHOUTS of warning.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SEA
dialogues.text: The sun cracks over the black water. John's hands move the rough wooden oars. Blistered palm opens. BLOOD flows. He tears off a piece of his cassock -- Rips it with his teeth -- Wraps the bloody hand. Rows.

dialogues.speaker: THE STAR
dialogues.text: Ship.  Star Ship. Sulaco escape vehicle #4 rocks on the water. White metal skin blackened by the heat.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Rows right into it. His coracle pitches in the choppy surf.   He scrambles onto the ship's cracked tile surface. Teeters -- balances -- moves to the unmistakeable HATCH. Looks around for a knob, a handle --

dialogues.speaker: NEXT TO THE HATCH
dialogues.text: A small panel door whose black and yellow stripes denote urgency.  John hesitantly opens the door, revealing a shi metal LEVER.  He stares at it...a beat. Then quickly pulls it down...

dialogues.speaker: WUORRRSH -
dialogues.text: Hull door OPENS. The doorway is a black maw. John crosses himself. Begins to lower his foot into the hatch -- KYLE O/S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it! He almost falls backwards off the ship.  Looks back --

dialogues.speaker: THE OTHER MONKS
dialogues.text: Are rapidly approaching. Kyle gestulates wildly -- KYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John!  Wait -- !  Don't go in! John turns back to the open hatch. Machine recirculated air flows out. He feels it on the skin of his face.  Cool. Cool, and artificial.  It calls to him. He steps in.  Swallowed by the blackness --

dialogues.speaker: WHOOSH-CLANG -
dialogues.text: The door closes behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  Dim red lights.  John stands still as his eyes adj the darkness.  He sees:

dialogues.speaker: NEWT'S HYPER SLEEP TUBE
dialogues.text: A glass and metal COFFIN -- pneumatic piping twines aroun base.  The glass lid is BROKEN.  A Small RED LIGHT pulses head of the tube -- a soft VOICE and TONE, like your seat warning -- is audible... COMPUTER VOICE (sotto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seal broken...seal broken... John finds himself moving towards the tube... Looks through the broken lid:

dialogues.speaker: IN THE TUBE
dialogues.text: There is a splattered BLOOD STAIN on the sterile white interior.  OLD, turned rust-brown. Whatever happened here happened a while ago. Rust colored drips trail down to --

dialogues.speaker: THE FLOOR
dialogues.text: Drag marks.  His eyes follow the stains to a pile of Bloody clothing against a control panel.  A jumpsuit.  To Child size.  The head of child's DOLL, but no body to be

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Looks back towards the door. Part of him wants to get the hell out here -- but he figh back his fear.  He is a doctor - or trying to be - someon in here may need his help.  He presses forward --  Averts his gaze from the clothing, UP to the blinking and glowing instrument panels and their myraid --

dialogues.speaker: LIGHTS
dialogues.text: Pressure lights.  Data lights.  Warning lights. Thousands of lights.  Like the stars in the sky. It's been decades since he's seen technology like this -- never this close up.  He steps further into the ship, his now replaced by fascination, follows the lights....

dialogues.speaker: ON A PALE GREEN SCREEN
dialogues.text: LED numbers race -- 7,291.01.05...06...07 A legand identifies "Elapsed since separation." He moves on...

dialogues.speaker: A VIDEO MONITOR
dialogues.text: Through scanning bars of snow, an image: A WOMAN with a YOUNG GIRL standing in front of her. The Woman's arms are wrapped around the girl. Protective. Maternal. The Woman speaks.  Her message repeats itself. A tape loop, although John has no idea what that is. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...taking pod four.  The Crew of the SS Sulaco and all Marine commandoes are dead. Ship's sensors have interrupted the hyper sleep cycle.  An overlooked alien egg has hatched.  Bishop and Hicks have been killed. Xenomorphs have infested the cruiser.  Newt  and I are taking pod four.  The Crew of... The WARNING TONE of the Woman's message rekindles John's He moves more hesitantly around the periphery of the ship following the trail of blinking instruments -- Drawn to touch a button.  Click...

dialogues.speaker: SOMETHING TENTACLE-LIKE DROPS DOWN ON HIS SHOULDER
dialogues.text: Just an oxygen mask. John feels his rapidly BEATING heart as he pushes aside t plastic, dangling object and continues around the shuttle His hand brushes over a SENSOR which responds by lighting

dialogues.speaker: HSSSSSSSSS -
dialogues.text: A BLAST of freon shoots out of an overhead pipe -- John SHOUTS and back up into --

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER HYPER SLEEP TUBE
dialogues.text: Next to Newt's now empty tube. Humming gently.  Still operational. John approaches it cautiously. He can make out the occupant through the lid...

dialogues.speaker: A WOMAN
dialogues.text: The woman from the screen.  This is RIPLEY. In hypersleep.  Wearing a white cotton tank top and boxer shorts.  Christ, she looks beautiful.   John looks from Ripley to her image on the monitor, then Sinks to his knees, reverent.  Fascination has replaced f again.  Moves his face closer to the lid.   Closer to hers... DAYLIGHT spills in -- John's head WHIPS towards the source of the light --

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Open.  Kyle and the other monks. KYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John - what is it?  Is this a Supply ship? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No supplies.  Kyle, there's someone in here -- The Second Monk looks at Kyle. SECOND MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is forbidden. KYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John.  Just get the hell out of there -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to stay.  I have to get her out before this sinks.  You come in, give me a hand -- KYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her?  Look, this is not the supply ship, so this is technology forbidden to us. Get out of there now! John looks down at Ripely. A KEYPAD is mounted at the head of the tube. A red button:  "EMERG-OPEN" That's plain enough. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- He presses it. The Tube opens with a loud BLAST of compressed air. The Monks at the door recoil at the sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ripley has been lowered into a large coracle.  John holds front of him.  Unconscious.   Her head lolls as the boat rocks on the waves.  The monks start to row back to short. FIRST MONK (reverent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A space ship... SECOND MONK (even more reverent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman... KYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have gone in -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to be a doctor. He pushes Ripley's hair away from her forehead. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could've been lost. FIRST MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been a long time since I saw either. SECOND MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't sinking.  Look at it.  What are we supposed to do with it? KYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it like in there --? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights.  So many lights -- THIRD MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tow it in.  Bring it in. SECOND MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's evil. FIRST MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just technology. SECOND MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evil technology.  Look at these fish -- THIRD MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Abbot will know what we should do with it -- KYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just lights? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Machines.  Buttons.  Metal. SECOND MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?  Just look at the fish. THIRD MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Abbot will know. SECOND MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're boiled.  These fish are boiled.  JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thousands of lights.  Like the stars. Like Heaven on Earth. Ripley stirs in John's arms.  Groans. Fights to come out of her fugue state... Looks around through half-lidded eyes -- She is surrounded by rowing, cassocked Monks. MONKS?  She closes her eyes. Tries to clear the imagine.  Opens: They're still there. She looks down at the bloodied hands around her waist -- realizes she's sitting on someone's lap. Looks back over her shoulder --

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He smiles at her. Friendly, not sexual.

dialogues.speaker: RIPLEY
dialogues.text: Shakes her head.  Tries to speak -- Her lips form soundless words. She looks over her other shoulder, sees --

dialogues.speaker: THE SHIP
dialogues.text: Bobbing on the surface.   Growing small with each stroke of the oars.

dialogues.speaker: RIPLEY
dialogues.text: Brows knit.  Fights the cobwebs in her brain. Tries to focus on the ship -- Remembers.  Turns to John, tries to speak -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.  New... She loses consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Streaks of light move across the darkness. Form patterns of light and shadow against the wooden wall There is a sublime stillness, but coming through the wall the muted, far off SOUNDS of the Abbey -- The SAWING of wood.  HAMMERING. WHISPERED prayers. LILTING song. We move down off the wall to a hand-made wooden bed. Ripley in restless sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waters grown rough with the approach of night.  Wind white wave tops -- SPRAYS the dozen Monks who LASH their  boats to Ripley's SHIP with thick hemp ropes -- Start to tow it to shore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ripley is sleeping -- but struggling against some unseen She tries to sit up -- can't.  Tries to shake off the eff the suspended animation...looks up through half-lidded ey

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Sits next to her.  Quite asleep. Hands swathed in white bandages.  Book resting on his lap She squints to make the figure standing in the shadows behind him -- it's skin picks up and reflects tiny points flickering cangle light - seems to ripple as it moves --

dialogues.speaker: THE ALIEN
dialogues.text: Big, black shiny-smooth head moves into the taper light. It moves towards her, cable-like arms held out at its sid moving out of sync with its feet -- Ripley tries to move to cry out -- She can't. She can only move her eyes.  She looks over at John, slee peacefully.  He doesn't notice the Alien -- The Alien moves closer.   She can feel his breath -- it evaporates the sweat  on he forehead -- a CHILL runs through her but she still can't The Alien stands alongside her bed. Extends a six-fingered hand... Gently rests it on her stomach. Cocks its head -- like it's listening to something. The implication is clear. Ripley finds her voice -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: AAAAAAAAAAAARGH
dialogues.text: Her eyes open wide -- She sits bolt upright. A hand moves to her forehead.  Gently pushes her head bac the pillow.  John's. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're out of it.  Out of it... Ripley falls back, eyes glued to where the alien appeared John sees her focal point, looks back over his shoulder: Nothing. Ripley's eyes roll back into her head. She tries to speak -- It was there. Her hand, at her side, tightens into a fist -- John's hand covers hers. Eases the fingers open again. She feels the coarse bandages against her palm. He starts to read quietly from Saint Augustines' Confessi She begins to drowse again as his soft voice flows over h like waves lapping against the shore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HOWLING DUST STORM has kicked up.  The monks wear small goggles, have rags tied over their noses, as they work at huge BLOCK AND TACKLE arrangement -- Hundreds of ropes grow TAUT. Timbers GROAN. They LIFT Ripley's SHIP -- SWING it over to a large porta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ripley lays with eyes closed. Muffled VOICES outside her door: ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is the woman, John? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think she's here yet. At the sound of John's voice the SLIGHTEST smile plays  across Ripley's sleeping lips. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is close, though. As they continue talking, Ripley wakes.  Opens her eyes. Rolls over onto her side -- There is a window right next to the bed. Ripley lifts herself up on one elbow, looks out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garden of Earthly delights... Monks laboring under a beautiful, celestial blue sky -- picking apples, fishing on the water on small inland lake Working with hammer and saw on small wooden cottages.  Ly It makes her feel good.  She scans the countryside... Sheep graze around wooden ladders stretching hundreds of up to the -- Ripley does a take --

dialogues.speaker: WORKERS ON A SCAFFOLDING
dialogues.text: With crude brushes at the end of poles -- PAINT the sky b The Abbey, the cottages, the fields outside her window ar on one level - INSIDE THE PLANET. The vaulted CEILING, painted to look like the sky with hu glass "windows" to allow the sunlight in, is actually the UNDERSIDE of the planetoid's outer shell. Ripley looks back at the Monks on the ground: Instead of repairing, they are taking the cabins apart, s the wood onto push carts -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell --?

dialogues.speaker: SUDDENLY --
dialogues.text: The Sulaco Escape ship APPEARS in front of her. SWINGS past her window suspended by ropes. Then disappears up, out of sight. Ripley checks her pulse. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This must be a dream.  A bad one. She rolls back onto the bed. Stares up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE HER
dialogues.text: Monks scurry around the Ship as it is lowered into place a flat area of the roof above the libaray. It seats with a deeply resounding THUD...

dialogues.speaker: RIPLEY
dialogues.text: Hears the SOUND and then another - her door OPENING. She turns to find the Abbot and John standing in the door John waits in the doorway as the Abbot crosses to the cha the bed and sits. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the Abbot.  Leader of this Colony. And you? He smiles.  Open.  Friendly. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ripley.  How did I get here? ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your vehicle crash landed. (indicates John)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother John found you and brought you here. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is here? ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the Minorite Abbey within the manmade orbiter Arceon. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I use a radio to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have no radio here.  We are a monastic order that has renounced all modern technology.  We live the old way.  The pure way. She shakes her head. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I - I still don't feel 100%.  Whoever took me out of the stasis tube must not  have run the full D-F program... Where's Newt? The Abbot looks at her blankly. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a little girl with me -- ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were alone. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  She was with me.  I put her in her stasis tube -- We launched when the -- ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were the only living thing found aboard that vessel. The Abbot watches Ripley as the terrible truth overcomes RIPLEY (slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God.  Newt. She stops -- gets that chill up her spine -- She realizes that she MUST have brought the Alien with he RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It came with us. The Abbot leans in. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What came with you? RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen -- there is a danger here.  It came with me.  How long have I been here? ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost two days -- RIPLEY (calculates)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loose for two days.  This planet could be overrun within the week. Ripley grabs the Abbot by his cassock -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, there's a xenomorph -- (sees his confusion)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Alien creature.  A killer.  A monster. And now it's here. The Abbot looks at her the way you look at that guy on th of Santa Monica and 3rd who's babbling about Judgement Da guy with his pants down around his kness. She sees this, releases her hold on him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down, Ripley.  Okay, I was with a platoon of Colonial Marines on a mission to planetoid LV426.  We left Earth six months ago - maybe a year -- ABBOT (interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a moment -- The Abbot becomes aware of John's presence in the doorway Turns over his shoulder at him. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave us. John waits there a beat, then backs out and closes the do ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continue. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We launched in the Cruiser Sulaco from  Gateway sub-orbital space station -- ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not possible. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we left Earth seventy years ago, it was on the brink of a New Dark Age. Technology was on the verge of destroying the planet's environment.  A computer virus was threatening to wipe away all recorded knowledge.  There didn't seem to be any way it could be averted.  In the almost forty years since we were towed out here in hypersleep, the news that came with  occasional supply ships only got worse. Finally, the ships stopped coming.  We  had to resign ourselves to the fact that worst had come to pass, and the Earth no longer existed. Now she gives him that look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIPLEY (slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...All right... Forget the Earth - How many people do you have here?  Let's worry about them.  Warn them -- A new look overtakes the Abbot's face.  A look of fear.   Now she's getting to him - or is she? He abruptly stands.  ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mind is troubled.  You need to rest some more. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need rest - I need to get to  your people.  You've got to get to them -- tell them about the alien -- He heads for the door -- ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have had enough for now. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough?  Didn't you hear what I said? It could wipe out the entire population of this planet.  It may have started  already - Have there been any unusual  deaths since I got here? The Abbot stops in the door - ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  And there won't be. The Abbot SLAMS the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORRIDOR OUTSIDE RIPLEY'S ROOM
dialogues.text: John stands nearby as the Abbot addresses two BURLY MONKS ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bolt it. The guards move to bolt the door. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it -- What's wrong? ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your patient is in a dangerous mental state.  Nobody gets in or out until I say so. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I.  Her meals -- ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, I don't understand -- The Abbot turns and disappears down the hall. John looks from the departing Abbot to the two Guard/Monk

dialogues.speaker: THE LIBRARY
dialogues.text: John has his head buried in his hands.  His back rises an with the rhythmic breathing of sleep. Mattias curled up on his feet.  Asleep as well.

dialogues.speaker: WHAM
dialogues.text: The Library door FLIES open --! John sits bolt upright --  A HYSTERICAL MONK bursts in. Rushes to John's table. HYSTERICAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother John!  You're here!  The Abbot said you'd -- I need -- you're the medic -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! HYSTERICAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Sandy -- she's ill -- John tries to rub the fitfull sleep out of his eyes. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?  A woman? HYSTERICAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandy.  My ewe. John returns his head to the table. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of your sheep?  Jesus Christ. Call a vet. HYSTERICAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Anselm was the vet. John looks under his arms at Mattias -- The dog just stares at him. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're no help.  Okay, let me get my bag. All creatures great and small...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small structure housing a handful of sheep and a few ch in wire cages.  The wooden walss are full of gaps where b have been ripped off. The Hysterical Monk holds a torch to illuminate the scene his sheep is laying on its side... HYSTERICAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just gave her dinner and she keeled over. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So would I.  It's freezing in here. HYSTERICAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been using the wood from the walls for the fire in my cabin. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't we all... John kneels at the ewe. She's breathing heavy.  Rapidly. John puts his left hand down on the hay covered floor whi checks the animal's neck pulse with his right hand.   She gives a weak "Baa-ah." JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May be pneumonia.  Pitch some of that hay around her.  Stop this damn cold breeze. The Hysterical Monk props the torch up in an empty bucket retreives a crude iron pitchfork from the wall. Starts to pile hay around the fallen animal. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, I'll -- He sits up to reach for his back, then stops when he sees on his left hand --

dialogues.speaker: A SLIMY MUCOUS-LIKE SUBSTANCE
dialogues.text: JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... The Hysterical Monk stops on mid-pitch. John rubs the material between his fingers. Brings it close to his nose.  Sniffs. HYSTERICAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  It's all over the ground. Some sort of --

dialogues.speaker: BAAA-AAAH
dialogues.text: The ewe starts to SHAKE - QUIVER -- John tries to hold it down -- The Hysterical Monk, at this juncture, goes completely ap HYSTERICAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!  WHAT?! JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus!  Help m -- The ewe is shaking so violently that John is thrown back He knocks over the bucket -- the torch falls into the hay The light is cut off as the torch almost smothers. Then the hay starts to burn -- Weak fire light revealing: BAAaa-Aha-SCLORTCH-H-!!

dialogues.speaker: THE EWE EXPLODES ---
dialogues.text: Stomach BURSTS -- SPRAYING the two Monks with entrails and blood -- They start SCREAMING. The flickering FIRE LIGHT grows as...

dialogues.speaker: A TERRIBLE ALIEN CHEST-BURSTER
dialogues.text: BURSTS out of the jerking and twitching carcass. It shows the characteristics of the animal in which it ha gestated.  Tiny razor sharp teeth and black, glass-like e peer from a enlongated head covered with downy, but gore- WOOL.  A quadroped, its shrunked hind legs struggling to itself from the cooling morass of intestines. John can only SCREAM as the most horrible nightmare he ca imagine tries to slough off the animal's mortal coil. The Hysterical Monk, fear overcome with ANGER at the loss his beloved Sandy,  steps in front of the near catatonic and instinctively THRUSTS his pitchfork into the creature The sharp prongs PIERCE its still forming body -- The CREATURE WAILS a high pitched SHRIEK - half alien, half sheep as i roughly TORN from it's nesting place -- The Monk lifts -- It TWISTS at the end of the fork, acid blood dripping ont wood floor -- each drop bursting into a little pool of FI The Hysterical Monk turns to the now raging hay fire -- The entire corner of the barn is ablaze -- SHOVES the abomination in -- The Sheep/Alien POPS and SIZZLES as tongues of flame leap lap at it's struggling body -- tiny tail whipping about - The creature dies, its fading screams are soon the only s heard within the barn.  The Hysterical Monk holds his for the flame as he looks back to check on --

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Face contorted, eyes glued to the burning creature.  Heav lungs push air through his diaphram, but no sound comes f his open mouth -- The Doctor in training has seen the dev

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wooden walls collapse inward as the building becomes a py Acrid black smoke curls up to the ceiling and spreads out across the rafters... We pull back from the sight INTO a window. Into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ripley, watches the burning barn.  Frustrated, she climbs the bed on unsteady legs, wearing her tank top and shorts Pulls on a coarse wollen cassock, ties the rope belt -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Idiots...I'll --

dialogues.speaker: WHAM
dialogues.text: The door BURSTS OPEN -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the -? Four BURLY MONKS rush in and grab her. TEAR her out of bed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ripley is dragged down the darkened hallway. ABBOT V.O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An evil has come to Arceon...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE TRIBUNAL ROOM
dialogues.text: As he continues we move down a row of stern Monk faces, e at the Abbots... ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard Brother Graham tell of the devil inside sheep's wool -- He motions towards the Hysterical Monk, sitting in the cr ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An evil brought by this woman in her vessel of technology.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: A large circular room with wooden walls stretching thirty high.  Light creeps in through stained glass windows. Hundreds of monks sits in a gallery that looms over the floor of the Tribunal.  On the floor: The Abbot and the five eldest Monks sit at a long table f the witness stand.  On the stand:

dialogues.speaker: RIPLEY
dialogues.text: Considers the faces that surround her.  Fear.  Hate. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This can't be happening. BALD TRIBUNAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no voice in this tribunal. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must listen to me!  You're all in terrible danger!  It came with me on the ship -- ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know that.  At first we believed its arrival was a good omen.  But it has only brought pestilence.  Dead sheep.  Dead fish. BALD TRIBUNAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evil. Ripley turns to the Abbot. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, the ship brought it.  Not evil. It brought the Alien.  I told you, it's here. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know the name of the evil it brought. It brought technology.  Technology to destroy our planet, as surely as it destroyed the Earth. MONK IN AUDIENCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Destruction! RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was on the Earth less than a year ago. It's still there.  People, cities, all  still there! A murmur through the crowd.  Some are listening to her. The Abbot looks around.  He must be in command. ABBOT (matter of fact)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All dead. RIPLEY (screams)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's still there! The Abbot smiles to himself for making her crack. He stands and begins to pace. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could not have been on the Earth a year ago, because there is no Earth to be on -- for at least twenty years. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been floating in space for twenty years.  Let me get to my ship and I'll prove it. BALD TRIBUNAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Who knows what new evils she'll release if allowed back into that infernal machine. MONK IN AUDIENCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  Don't let her!! TRIBUNAL MEMBER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This woman is a danger.  She denies The New Dark Age.  She denies reality. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is reality.  There is a Xenomorph loose on this planetoid - a alien -- it must have stowed away on my ship -- must have killed -- (swallows hard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newt.  Killed the girl I brought with me. You can't stop it.  It goes inside you like an egg - grows - (mimes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explodes out of you - keeps growing into some sort of monster.  Kills you -- Kills all of you... She looks at the Medieval people around her. They stare at her in complete confusion. To them, she does sound like a madwoman. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you people?  Look at you -- all of you -- the way you're dressed.  This isn't the Middle Ages.  You're in space -- on a artifical planet.  What are you doing out here? There, in the upper tier -- John.  They make eye contact. She looks to him pleadingly. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there anyone here who will listen? John looks from Ripley to the Abbot. The Abbot stares him down. John turns away. RIPLEY (defeated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess not.  I can't believe this... The gavel BANGS. The Abbot sits in a moment of contemplation. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then there is no choice. The Four Monks grab Ripley roughly -- Bind her arms. ABBOT (to Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The evil is inside you.  I cast you down. To be sealed away.  And God have mercy on your soul.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHAFT ROOM
dialogues.text: A Medieval elevator shaft.  The "elevator" is a wooden ca lowered on thick, rough hewn ropes. Ripley, bound, is led to it. She looks back at the monks who have gathered at the door RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't be able to fight it... You don't know what it is --! She's put into the cage.  The door is secured. Two monks begins to pull the ropes.  The cage is lifted o the abyss -- a vast cavernesque space. The other Monks move closer.  Crowd around the edge -- John pushes through them - right to the edge -- Watches as the cage is slowly lowered down... Ripley looks directly at John -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've sentenced yourselves to  death! John watches as she disappears down into the darkness... Then turns and pushes his way through the crowd -- Down the hall --

dialogues.speaker: THE TRIBUNAL ROOM
dialogues.text: Empty now except for the Abbot and the Tribunal Members. They speak in hushed tones. John appears in the doorway, but pauses - strains to hear what they are saying: BALD TRIBUNAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...they'll have started before she gets down to the Hermitage level. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No trouble? BALD TRIBUNAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only finding the wood for the ship.  But Anderson's hut was about that big, and he's dead three months now. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had that wood earmaked for the Cloister  next winter.  Well, we might not get to the winter if we don't take care of this. By winter time we can start taking the  penitent cells apart.  No one in them. ANOTHER TRIBUNAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wood isn't going to last forever. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither are we -- He becomes aware of John's presence, and motions the othe Tribunal members out of the room.  John moves to the Abbo The Abbot knows what's coming... ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This woman.  Ripley.  I tended her -- ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and you did a good job.  You shouldn't feel responsible.  You couldn't have known -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, sir, let me finish.  I feel that there may be something to what she says. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't. The Abbot moves to his table, begins to gather up his gav notebook.  John follows him -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand what you are doing. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This colony is my responsibility.  I am protecting the colony. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what?  This woman?  You never gave her a chance.  How can you be so sure you're right? ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A better question is what makes you think I'm wrong? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't see this thing -- this demon -- Brother Graham and I -- we both saw it. ABBOT (realizes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  You both did. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what was it? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I don't know what it was.  But I don't think Ripley was a party to it. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She admits she brought it. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she tried to warn us -- ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that's how the devil works. Deception. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I believe her.  I don't know how to describe it -- A feeling. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't seen a woman in thirty years. Where does this feeling originate, John? JOHN (points to his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Pause. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you.  But your feelings are fooling you.   JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's - It's her conviction.  I just think -- The Abbot snaps at him -- ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think. John takes a step back at the Abbot's tone.  A tone he's heard before.  The Abbot runs a hand through his thinning Forces a smile. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a long night.  For all of us. You really don't understand what you're dealing with here. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what she said. The Abbot chafes. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are ideas which threaten the very system we live under.  The creature is dead and the woman is gone.  Forget them. Both.  Go read.  Go fishing.  Go anywhere, but leave this alone. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I -- ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone.  I'll get Philip to let Mattias into the Library, all right?  For your own good, just stay out of this. John looks like he's going to protest. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it. JOHN (slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Father. John turns and leaves the room.   The Abbot stares after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. Dank. Dreary. A NAIL is hammered into a board.  Then another. The board is old, twisted.  The grain is pronounced, spli Another board is lifted into place, a nail held -- BAM-BA HAMMERED in tight.

dialogues.speaker: TWO ANCIENT WORKERS
dialogues.text: Drab, torn gray clothing. Hammer the boards over the opening in the wall. Methodically covering up --

dialogues.speaker: RIPLEY
dialogues.text: Watching them work. BAM-BAM-BAM. Defeated.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ROOF OF THE ABBEY, (INTERCUT)
dialogues.text: A dozen Monks frantically hammer planks up around the Sul escape ship - A frame of wood -- begin to wall it in...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE PRISON LEVEL
dialogues.text: The two ANCIENT WORKERS continue their carpentry. The planks cover more of the opening. BAM-BAM-BAM. Covers more of Ripley. BAM-BAM-BAM. She stares...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ROOF OF THE ABBEY
dialogues.text: Planks are rising around the ship. Covering it.  Locking away the good omen turned evil.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIBRARY
dialogues.text: John and Mattias sit before an open book. He doesn't read.  He can hear the POUNDING of the hammers It seems to reverberate THROUGH the planet. Through his SKULL. He closes his eyes in pain.

dialogues.speaker: RIPLEY
dialogues.text: Only her face is visible. Another board. BAM-BAM-BAM. Then just her eyes. Just before the last plank is put in place -- WORKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go, woman.  Something from your ship.  Something to keep you company -- He tosses it into the cell.  Ripley catches it. Watches as the last of the light is covered over. BAM-BAM...BAM. She continues to stare at the once open wall as her eyes accustomed to the darkness.  The little light creeping be the planks grows in intensity until it is soon enough to what it is she has caught -- NEWT'S DOLL'S HEAD. Ripley looks around her cell -- actually a narrow space b other cells, one wall curved out -- like a narrow slice crossways towards the edge of the pie.  Looks at the Doll's head in her hand. A beat. She FREAKS OUT --! RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fucking idiots!  You're dead! You're all dead! BEATS the walls.  KICKS. SMASHES her HEAD against the wall. Again. Her nose starts to bleed. Her hand goes to her nose. She squints in the darkenss. Sees the BLOOD. Tastes the iron taste in her mouth. Death is with her again. RIPLEY (sotto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead... The "widest" part of her cell, the middle, allows her to down into a sitting position.  She does. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ.  Jesus Christ.  It's here.  Here. Shit.  Here.  I can't get rid of it... Looks at the Doll's head -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newt.  This isn't what I wanted... She throws the doll's head away -- It bounces off the wall and rolls back to an upright posi so that it is staring at her. RIPLEY (snaps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't stare at me! Beat. VOICE O/S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Ripley looks down at the base of the wall facing her -- Where it meets the floor, in the rotting timbers: A HOLE.  In it:

dialogues.speaker: A MAN'S FACE
dialogues.text: Bright, wrinkled eyes beneath a snowy white crew cut. He's looking back at her.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ROOF OF THE MONASTERY
dialogues.text: The Sulaco escape pod #4 is now a memory as the Monks hav finished walling it up.  Now just another part of the Abb As the Monks move down the thin wooden ladders we follow Pass them -- down to an open window and into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is here, Mattias asleep at his feet. The tables, the benches, the floor are COVERED with hundr books he's pulled off the shelves, their chains all TANGL All open to --

dialogues.speaker: PICTURES OF DEVILS
dialogues.text: Different representations of Evil through the ages -- Lucifer, Shaitan, Ahriman, Asmodeus -- Satan. "The Temptation of Christ" from the Master of Schloss Lichtenstein.  Satan roasting on an enormous grill from "Tres riches heures du Duc de Berry." The devil as a serpent.  As a semi-humanoid. Gruenwald's "Temptation of St. Anthony." Pacher's "Saint Wolfgang and the Devil." A miasma of Medieval Monsters.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Picks his way through the mess.  Like a man possessed he through book after book. The first golden rays of daylight filter through the huge stained glass windows.  John rapidly flips through the Me tome in front of him - past an illustration of Satan depi as having a FACE on his ASS -- further still -- then stop This is it. We can't see what the illustration is, but we see his REA His eyes open wide as saucers.  SLAMS the book closed as image would strike blind.  He turns to Mattias as if to s something -- Decides not to wake the sleeping dog. John wraps the book's chain around his hand and puts one up against the shelf.  Pulls -- SPANKT! The old chain gives way. Face set, he loops the shoulder strap of his burlap medic over his shoulder.  Clutches the book to his chest, gentl his sleeping dog and goes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John strides down the corridor purposefully but stops and flattens himself against the wall when the door to the Ab office opens suddenly -- BROTHER GRAHAM, The Hysterical Monk, is forcibly led from room by two burly Monks, taken down the corridor in the o direction.  He is gagged.  A third Burly Monk moves out o doorway with the Abbot. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now find John and have him brought to  me immediately. THIRD BURLY MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Father. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start in the library.  And keep it quiet.  The Third Burly Monk nods and moves off. The Abbot watches him leave, then goes back into the room closes the door.  John stares at the closed door a beat a makes up his mind.  He turns and runs back down the hallw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first Monks straggle in for the morning shift. Kyle is among them.  He lifts his blowing iron from a wal mounted rack and moves towards the glass furnace as two other Monks begin to stoke the fire. John enters. Looks around the room and for a frantic moment cannot fin

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: At the glass furnace.  About to dip his blowing iron into MOLTEN GLASS.  John runs over to him. Almost knocks him over -- KYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  Watch it! He sees that John is agitated -- KYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  What is it? The other monks begin to notice the commotion, start movi for a look... JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- Abbot.  Must -- John tries to catch his breath.  He gestulates wildly. Kyle puts down his blowing iron. KYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John - relax.  Take a deep breath - Christ, now I sound like you -- He sees the book clutched in John's white knuckled hands. KYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that it, John?  Is it the book --? JOHN (panting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Devil. Kyle moves closer to him.  Cautiously. John sees the other monks gathering around -- Closing in on him - whispering -- WHISPERING MONKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got it... SECOND WHISPERING MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the Comet Woman... THIRD WHISPERING MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He found her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHISPERING MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's infected... John sees one of the Monks run out -- undoubtedly going t the Abbot.  John looks into his friend Kyle's face -- Fea KYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's gonna be fine.  Now, let's see the -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't humor me -- I'm --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  Everything's gonna be fine... If only he could explain - he can't. John YANKS the book away -- spins -- Bursts through the crowd... KYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait -- JOHN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cage is still down, the ropes stretching into the aby John runs in.  Moves to the ropes.  Places the book on th Tightens his scarred hands on the rope -- Mind racing:   The woman will know.  Know what it is.  How to combat it. He PULLS -- There's no tension against the ropes. John FALLS back on his ass. The ropes WHIZ through the rusty pulley overhead. Pile on the floor in front of John.  He lifts the end of the rope.  Stares: BITTEN THROUGH.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE MONASTERY
dialogues.text: John RUNS through the building. Through the upper half of the planet. DOWN through the many levels, past dozens of Monks oblivi the previous night's events and the danger they face: Monks working at Looms. Monks in the Tanning Room. Monks in Morning Prayer. Past them all, to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mops and brooms. John enters.  His hair is wild, breathing heavy. He shoves the book into his medical bag. Pushes aside a box of kindling wood to reveal a WOODEN DOOR set into the timbers of the floor. He opens the door:

dialogues.speaker: LADDERS
dialogues.text: Extending down through huge open areas beneath the upper Past vast underground viaducts that held up by wooden raf Beyond that - a great underground sea that marks the cent the planet - below that, the cells. And Ripley.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Can smell the dank air from the lower tunnels. He MUST go down -- The hard way. He climbs into the darkness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An enormous room, over a football field in length, consis of at least a hundred open toilet STALLS facing a hundred mounted SINKS.  Their condition, though, bespeaks the awf truth - The stalls furthest away from us are COBWEBBED. Some have had the side walls stripped for fire wood. Of the original hundred sinks, maybe twenty are still functional - A facility created for a much larger number colonists than are left. A SKINNY MONK washes his hands.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STALLS
dialogues.text: Moving down the row of stalls (chest high, thank you) pas few empty stalls and several grimacing faces, the second last being The Abbot -- ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold tonight -- -- continuing to the last, Bald Tribunal Member. BALD TRIBUNAL MEMBER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gets colder every night. ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And every day.  Never this bad.  Taken so much wood out of the structure the surface wind blows right through the colony.  Right under the floor -- The Bald Tribunal Member SHIVERS as a cold breeze runs al waste trough under the floor and chills the air in his bo BALD TRIBUNAL MEMBER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right up your bloody backside.  Nights like this make me miss plumbing --  Ack --! He feels a TUGGING at his bowels - it's not piles.  A beat. ABBOT O/S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? BALD TRIBUNAL MONK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't -- AAH -- The Bald Tribunal Monk SCREAMS as something GRABS him fro below -- (note: the left half of the following 5 pages is cut off. I have completed the text to the best of my ability.) Something SNAKES up his rectum and hooks into his lower i He convulses in spasms of agony. There is a terrible RIPPING SOUND as the Bald Tribunal Mo PULLED VIOLENTLY down -- out of frame -- We PAN BACK down the row of stalls tight on each sitting and see their HORRIFIED REACTION as they feel the ALIEN d Bald Tribunal Monk's body away under them... THE ABBOT in his stall He pounds on the wall -- ABBOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew?  Matthew?  Jesus, what's wrong? SKINNY MONK washing his hands, sees all this.  Looses con of his bodily functions as blood sprays from the faucet -

dialogues.speaker: OTHER MONKS
dialogues.text: In their stalls as the toilets reject a torrent of gore! Blood and viscera spraying the walls -- converting the Ab into an abattoir.

dialogues.speaker: SPACE
dialogues.text: Angle on the Orbitor Arceon: An orb of wood hands peacefully against a tapestry of cel seas. RIPLEY V.O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness.  Somewhere water drips into a puddle. Ripley lays on her side on the floor with her head restin near the hole in the floor.  Her eyes are closed. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wherever I go. A HAND pushes a crust of bread through the hole.  She opens her eyes to look at the food.  The White-Haired head appears -- WHITE-HAIRED MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, but no thanks, Anthony. She knows his name. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You waiting for meat?  They don't bring me meat because they know I'm an android. Really don't need it.  Bread's better for you anyway.  Harder to digest, so  it makes you feel fuller than you are. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not hungry. Anthony takes a bite. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm.  Just a little crunchy. Ripley twists onto her back until she's staring up at the ceiling. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waste of time. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't eat, you'll starve to death, girl. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the plan when they put me down here.  And why should you care? ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm a synthetic person you don't think I can care? RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, that's a discussion you don't want to have with me. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me you had a bad experience and a good one with androids -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one of each.  That means you could go either way.  I'm tired of talking about this. He pushes the bread towards her again. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've still gotta eat.  You gotta fight the bastards -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired of fighting.  Maybe I'll be dead before he finds me.  Maybe he won't get the satisfaction. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He?  You make it sound like this Alien has a personal score to settle with you. The biology you describe:  Queen laying eggs, larvae, drone -- that's very insectoid.  Insects usually don't bear grudges. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Androids usually aren't the prisoners of lunatics that believe they're ancient  Greeks. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medieval Monks. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever.         ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they've only chose to live the life style, they don't believe they're -- (hears something)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? Ripley strains to listen.  In the distance: KNOCKING.  Someone is knocking on the walls. A VOICE calls out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN (hoarse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ripley! He moves down the hallway. BANGS his fist against the walls every few feet -- Waits a moment for a reply, then moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony gets off the floor - Moves so she can see into hi The walls of Anthony's cell are covered with charcoal ske Different versions of demons and the devil.  She rolls he This guy is an Android! Anthony crosses to his cell door, peers through eye level

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John coming towards him, knocking on the doors of boarded ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- you knocking -- cut it out -- You're going to wake everybody up. John moves to Anthony's door.  Looks at him through the s Anthony recognizes him. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother John? John unbolts Anthony's door. Picks him up by his cassock -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony?  Thought you dead fifteen years. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Made too good for that.  What're you doing? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I'm looking -- the Abbot -- ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  You look like you've seen the devil. RIPLEY O/S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has. Anthony turns to look back at Ripley -- moves aside so Jo see her face at the hole -- ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean he -- Anthony turns back - John is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As John begins to PULL the outermosk planks off. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was right, wasn't I?  You've seen it, you've seen the Alien? John pauses at that.   His eyes tighten at the memory. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell you have.  I was right. It came with me. (to the wall, sharp)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away. John stops.  Looks at the wall. Ripley's voice comes clearly through the wood... RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, priest, or whatever you are, I know what you want.  I can't help you. I couldn't help any of the others.   Just stop what you're doing.  Go away. Do you understand? John has opened a crack that exposes Ripley's eyes.   He stares at her a beat, tries to think of what to reply He goes back to work as she continues her confession... RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to stay, Father?  But you're  not going to talk.  Okay.  Then you can listen.  You should listen.  Your Abbot was right.  I am guilty.  But not of  heresy.  Of murder. John stops again. Just stares at her eyes. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The murder of the crew of the Nostromo. That was when I first met the Alien. That reminds him of why he's here. He doubles his efforts at the boards... RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not the same one that's here now. Or maybe it is.  Maybe they're all the  same one.  I couldn't save my crew then. I should have been able to.  But I couldn't. When I went the second time -- Her eyes soften. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I met Newt.  Newt.  I fought -- stayed alive to keep Newt alive. Hoped maybe that would make up for... She trails off.  Slides down the wall. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he got her too.  What's the point? (hard again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just go away.  Leave me in here.  If you let me out you'll want me to help you and it will start all over again. Let it end. John breaks through, flickering torch light streams in th filled air around him.  Ripley looks up at him. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help you. John, heaving and panting from the excertion. Swallows... JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puh. (pant) Please. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It never ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long, twisted-plank-floored corridor with a torch every twenty feet.  There is MOVEMENT at the far end.  Somethin coming towards us - FLICKERING in and out of the light an shadow -- RIPLEY O/S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheep?

dialogues.speaker: RIPLEY, JOHN AND ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Running together.  Anthony carries a long wooden staff li spear.  John has his bag.  Ripley a torch.  We move with them. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be able to take on some of the characteristics of the animal it grows in. Maybe they are from some sort of aggressive soldier race -- warring parties drop the eggs on opposing planets -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the alien takes on the form of the creature that finds it, assuming that animal is the dominant life form on the planet.  So when it gestates in a man -- Ripley shudders at the memory. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a biped.  In a sheep or cow, a quadroped. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.  I just didn't think it could do that to animals. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute - I thought you were the expert on this monster. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the only reason you came to get me out?  Because I knew about this thing? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I mean no.  I mean, that was part of it.  Look.  I never thought you were wrong. I was wrong not to say anything.  I was afraid to speak up.  It's hard to be a  monk, you know? Ripley stops.  Looks at him. A long beat. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  If anything, you're honest. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all are.  Took vows. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about the Abbot. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he thinks what he did was right. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that speaking up for someone? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Charity. She smiles.  They turn a corner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This hallway slopes downwards a few degrees.  The three f themselves trotting, leaning backward to keep their balan RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let's forget about the past and get on to our survival.  No more prisoners behind us? ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for years. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay -- If the Alien's had a few days to lay his eggs our only hope is to get off this - What is this? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arceon. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satellite. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get to my ship and get off this Satellite. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't what? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave Arceon.  Can't leave the library -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Tape Library? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Books. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reason we are out here.  Like the Monks who guarded Monastery Libraries  on remote islands off England during the First Plague -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be books on other colonies -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of these books survived the burning of the Libraries of Alexandria.  They contain knowledge that exists in no  other record.  Their value is unestimable. He runs his hand along the spine of the book in his bag. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're supposed to protect them. RIPLEY (to Anthony)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what does an android have to do  with all this? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a spy. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Company planted me here. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Company?  What does the Company have to do with this? ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They built this prison. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prison? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colony. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prison.  They are all political heretics.   Ripley looks at John. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You left that part out. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The order was more of a counter culture, a reaction to the Technology that was beginning to take over everyone's lives. It was a simple enough idea - Read, don't  watch disk.  Walk, don't pump more carbons into the air.  The earliest members renounced technology.  Started to collect the remaining books.  Nobody would have noticed if it hadn't been for the Virus. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Abbot talked about that.  The New Plague. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A computer virus.  A bad program.  By this time the Corporate structure was transglobal, all the world's data storage systems were linked.  It spread through two countries before it was stopped. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a scare like that, thousands flocked to our retreat.  People started clamoring for written information.  For our books. They abandoned the modern ways -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I can see how this comes out.         They gave up their possessions. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was a threat -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the Company. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sold the technology.  A movement  to live simply was quickly twisted by  Federal agents into a political movement against the Company-controlled World Government.  Too much was at stake. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too much profit. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were sentenced as political dissidents. This orbiter is our gulag.  All the men were packed up with all our books, and towed into space.  Ten thousand men.  The eldest died very quickly. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Company had such a sense of irony.   Sending you out on this wooden tub. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was placed among them as a sensor. Keeps tabs on the movement. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how'd they find out about you? ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told them.  After the supply ship's stopped coming I saw no point in keeping up the charade.  Since I was a sort of walking reminder of technology, they cast me down. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Join the club. (to John)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured this wasn't planned.  You don't have to be a genius to see it wouldn't be prudent to try to preserve man's written works for generations -- without women. John looks embarrassed. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't know about your New Plague, but I was just on Earth and everything's  fine. John has a doubtful look. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was right about the Alien, wasn't I? Means I must be right about the Earth. The logic behind her argument is uncomfortable. JOHN (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's better than nothing.  Come on. They reach the end of the corridor. It opens into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An enormous open space between "cell blocks." The Wall behind them is honey-combed with corridor openin going up four stories, connected by aged, warped wooden l reminiscent of Indian cave dwellings.  Only wooden. The room stretches several football field lengths ahead o -- falling off into gloom. They stand silent for a moment, dwarfed by the size of th and the task ahead of them.  Finally -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At any rate, let's forget about the Earth completely - whether you're right or I'm right what's important is getting the hell out of here.  From here my ship is...? John points up at the ceiling. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Heaven. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  And this is... Anthony and John nod. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This orbiter was patterned after a  medieval concept of the universe -- (makes a circle in the air)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They call the top half "Heaven - " JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Abbey, the fields -- ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bottom half is "Hell."  Where we are. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aptly named.  What's in the middle? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sea. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work with me here.  How far is it back to the surface of the planet? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a stone falls --- Five miles through the center. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the elevator -- the thing they lowered me down in? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ropes cut. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's smart.  First he cuts their escape off, then works his way down through the  monastery level by level until there isn't a thing left alive.  Interesting... RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you start appreciating him more than me and I'll find a way to shut you down, capisce, Andy?  How do we get up? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are ladders. She stops.  John and Anthony continue on a few steps and stop and walk back to her. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five miles with the Alien between us and there?  Good luck, boys. She turns and heads back towards her cell -- John catches her shoulder -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't what?  Not help you go to your deaths?  I've had my fill of that. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you.  I can't do it alone. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've fought these creatures twice before.  It take a lot to kill these things.  Heavy artillery. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have weapons here. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about something we can make weapons from?  Do you have anything like that -- any modern things here? John SHAKES his head vehemently -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We renounced technology.  It was those things that caused the Plague. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a man-made planet.  Something has to be recirculating your air, your water. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God? RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I just took it for granted. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most people do.  Without some sort of technology we haven't got a chance. From behind them: ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is technology. John and Ripley turn to look at him. ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room.  A Technology room.  Fresh air and water come out. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An atmosphere processing plant -- ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heart and lungs of Arceon. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it? ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One level beneath the underground sea. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's five levels up -- ANTHONY (points into the gloom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other side of the orbiter. John looks at Ripley -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chance. Ripley looks from John's earnest face to the darkness and RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  You've got me - so far. But here's the deal:  I don't know how many of your brethren are going to be alive when we get up there, but if we make it to my ship, you're all coming with me.  We'll take as many of your precious books as we can carry, but we're going.  I'm not going to fight this thing again to  end up alone again.  Understand? John nods his head. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all dead anyway.  We might as well go fi -- She feels a TWINGE in her midsection -- Doubles over.  Anthony and John each take an arm -- RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh - I'm all right. She takes a deep breath. RIPLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still thawing out.  I hate hyper sleep... Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The formerly idyllic landscape has been reduced to a scor battlefield.  Wooden huts leveled.  Small fires dot the l The air thick with ash and greasy smoke. DOZENS OF MONKS swarm across the countryside like ants on mound of spilt sugar.  In one hand a taper or torch held in the other hand their WEAPON: scythe, pitchfork, hoe, whatever they could get ahold of, seem pitifully out of p Some pound sharpened stakes into the ground, others push into rough barricades. A "Platoon" of Monks huddle around trap doors open on the wooden "ground."  More ladders. They climb down to --

dialogues.speaker: AN UNDERGROUND WHEAT FIELD
dialogues.text: Just beneath the Monastery level of the satellite: an  Underground Wheatfield.  Tall golden grass stretches out miles, swaying gently around huge wooden columns that sup the Abbey fifty feet above --

dialogues.speaker: THE CEILING
dialogues.text: A lattice-work of suspended troughs and wooden pipes -- the "plumbing," the understructure, of the Monastery.

dialogues.speaker: THE MONKS
dialogues.text: Descend the ladders single file.  Fear is in all of their though most have only heard the stories.  They move cauti into the wheat.  Spread out through the field in the jagg drawn skirmish line.

dialogues.speaker: THE ABBOT
dialogues.text: The Bald Tribunal Monk's dried blood splattered on his ca stands atop an empty wooden wagon.  From this vantage poi watches

dialogues.speaker: THE MONKS IN THE FIELD
